R. & R. NEWS CO., ATLANTA, GA.
Stone Mountain, 16 miles from Atlanta, Ga. is the World's greatest monolith, and may properly be called "EIGHTH WONDER OF THE WORLD." It is seven miles around its base and rises 800 feet above the surrounding terrain, or 1600 feet above sea level. This mountain figured in the Spanish Expedition of De Soto about 1540. Indians established signal and watch towers on its summit. A huge Confederate Memorial is now being carved on its sheer side.

Library, Florida State College for Women

The color-added illustration depicts the library back when FSU was the College for Women. The building is a brick building with a grey roof. It has several large windows with stairs leading up to big wooden doors. Some of the windows are square, while others are arched, and the windows behind the tree and plants appear to have a design. There is a decorated window above the wooden doors. There is a walkway surrounded by green grass in front of the building as well as two trees in front of the building and some bushes. There is one lone bench in the grass. The sky is clear and blue with some clouds. This building is now Dodd Hall at the current FSU.^^This card is a color added image of the library at the Florida State College for Women. The building featured is a red, seemingly brick, building at the center of the card, and would later become Dodd Hall on Florida State University's campus. The card also features a green lawn and some trees in the foreground as well as a bench.

This is an interesting card. It looks to be an early form of a Valentine's card with children. There are two cartoon children drawn onto the card- one boy and one girl. The boy is dressed like a policeman and is extending his hand in a forceful motion, while the girl rides a hobby horse with a surprised look on her face. There is a small paragraph of text that accompanies the drawing. It was clearly handled by a child presumably nicknamed "Junior"- the writing on the back is haphazardly written all over the back, and the card has been damaged by water. The color illustration depicts a Valentine with a Valentine message. On the front are two little children. There is a boy who is dressed in a blue police officer outfit with a hat, belt, shiny shoes, and white gloves. The little boy is rosy cheeked with red or blonde hair.  The girl is riding a white and black spotted rocking horse with blondish brown hair. The horse has a shocked face on while having a saddle, stirrups and a harness. The little girl has a green dress with white short sleeves and high white socks and black shiny shoes. She has a brown hat on with a blue ribbon on it. The card is red with a white box for the message and the addition of a gravel ground under the boy and girl. There is wear and tear and the red color has bled through to the back of the card. The back of the card has also been worn down. There are leafy decorations are the word post card on the back.

From Who?
Mr. Junior Fraser
Moline, ILL
947. 25 ST
25

In the bottom right corner, the title of the card "Barcelona" is in an orange, playful font.

The entrance to Girard College in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, is the subject of this postcard. In the foreground, a black fence extends into two small buildings and then into a wall. An opened gate on the fence leads onto a stretch of green grass. A darker circular patch of grass has been landscaped in the center of the postcard with smaller circular pink beds of flowers and a white path cutting straight through the diameter of the circle. The path leads to the main building, which is gray, rectangular with a triangular roof and steps leading up to it. The door is tall and open. This building is a replica of the Parthenon in Greece.

VT 46
Vermont State Capitol, Montpelier, Vt. The present structure is the third since Montpelier was chosen the capitol in 1805. The first building was of wood, completed in 1808. The second was built of granite and completed in 1838. It was destroyed by fire in 1857. The present building was completed in 1859. An addition was built on the west side in 1885. The dome is built of wood& covered with gold leaf. The statue on the dome is of Ceres, Goddess of Agriculture.

The Berlin Cathedral, also known as the Berliner Dom, has a mix of neo-Renaissance and Baroque Revival styles. A great archway opens above the doors. People can be seen walking towards the stairs leading to the main doors. Levels of different sizes of columns surround the structure. The main dome, at its center, is flanked by two smaller domes. A view of the Brandenburg Gate and surrounding buildings in Berlin, Germany, with people in horse-drawn carts moving underneath it.

The famous historical landmark in Berlin known as the Brandenburg Gate, or in German, the "Brandenburger Tor" is the focus of this black and white scene.  It is 26 meters tall and forms a neoclassical triumphal arch, supported by columns in the Ionic-Doric style with 5 open entryways. The gate is made of sandstone and is decorated with scenes from the lives of Hercules, the Greek god Mars, and the goddess Minerva. At the top center of the gate stands a bronze sculpture of the goddess of victory riding a four-horse chariot to enter the city. On both sides of the gate stand two halls lined with columns and more buildings out to each side. People and horse carriages roam the square in front of it. A fountain can be seen to the left.

Berlin
Pariser Platz mit Brandenburger Tor

Canterbury Cathedral stands tall above the surrounding buildings. It boasts Romanesque and Gothic architecture. Flying buttresses support the main building, while three towers reach toward a cloudy sky. On the pavement below, a group of four, each wearing a different color (red, black, yellow, and blue), walk toward the massive structure. The Cathedral sits on a grassy lot, scarcely surrounded by trees.

This cathedral has several famous associations. It is the religious pilgrims' intended destination when traveling in Chaucer's The Canterbury Tales. It is also the place where Thomas Becket, the archbishop of Canterbury, was murdered during the 12th-century reign of King Henry II (through an unfortunate misunderstanding between the king and his guards). Supposedly, the king's guards murdered the archbishop on the altar of the cathedral.

June 23rd Sat.
I don't know if this is where Archbishop Michael hangs out - but thought you might enjoy seeing what [--] cathedral at Canterbury looks like. We were there today - took the train from London. About 1 1/2 hrs away. They have the exact spot marked where Thomas Becket was martyred. Lots of other interesting things too. We had our first real English lunch too - roast lamb & roast beef w/ Yorkshire pudding. Yesterday we took a trip to Oxford and spent hours walking through all the different colleges. It's a really beautiful town - lots of old buildings & churches. Canterbury & Oxford were rather peaceful compared to London - What a crush! Now it's sunny & hot and the sidewalks & buses are packed w/ people.
Twinkie

Ms. Anne Seed
397 College Avenue
Coalinga, California 93210
U.S.A.
